summary_points: 1. On March 24, 2025, Kimberly J. Harris resigned from the Board of Directors of American Water Works Company, Inc., effective immediately, citing personal health reasons.
2.  The filing is an 8-K report, indicating a significant event requiring immediate disclosure to the SEC.
3. The company intends to fill the vacancy created by Ms. Harris's resignation in the Nominating/Corporate Governance Committee Chair role at a later date.

1. Baker Hughes Company will make changes to its income statement presentation in its upcoming Form 10-Q for the quarter ended March 31, 2025, separating research and development costs and removing subtotals for operating and non-operating income (loss).
2.  Baker Hughes' net income attributable to the company increased from $(601) million in FY2022 to $2,979 million in FY2024 (recasted).
3. The SEC filing does not mention specific future impacts or risks associated with the changes to the income statement presentation beyond stating that historical results were not impacted.

1. On March 21, 2025, DexCom, Inc. dismissed Ernst & Young LLP as its independent registered public accounting firm and engaged Deloitte & Touche LLP as its replacement for the fiscal year ending December 31, 2025.
2. There were no disagreements or reportable events between DexCom and Ernst & Young during the two most recent fiscal years (ending December 31, 2024 and 2023) and the subsequent interim period.
3.  The SEC filing contains no specific future impacts or risks related to the change in auditors.
1. Dell Technologies' fiscal year 2025 net revenue increased by 8%, driven primarily by growth in Infrastructure Solutions Group (ISG) servers and networking.

2. Dell Technologies identified a material weakness in its internal control over financial reporting, resulting in revisions to previously issued financial statements for fiscal year 2024 and parts of 2025.

3.  As of January 31, 2025, Dell had $24.6 billion in total debt, a decrease of $1.4 billion year-over-year;  however, an 18% increase in its quarterly dividend rate is effective in the first quarter of fiscal year 2026.

1. Blackstone Inc. preliminarily estimates over $385 million in realized performance revenues and realized principal investment income for the period January 1, 2025 to March 25, 2025, primarily from performance revenues.
2. This preliminary estimate excludes the revenue from the sale of Bistro, which is expected to close before the end of the first quarter (March 31, 2025).
3.  Blackstone’s preliminary estimate for the period ending March 25th, 2025 is not predictive of the full first-quarter (ending March 31st, 2025) or full-year (ending December 31st, 2025) results.
1. On March 25, 2025, Target Corp closed the sale of $1 billion in 5.000% Notes due 2035.
2. The sale of the notes generated $992,570,000 in net proceeds for Target (before transaction expenses and after underwriting fees).

3.  The underwriting agreement includes extensive representations and warranties from Target regarding the legality and validity of the note issuance, and includes indemnification clauses for both Target and the underwriters in case of legal disputes relating to the notes.
1. Microchip Technology Inc. amended and restated its existing credit agreement on March 25, 2025, increasing its unsecured revolving loan facility to $2,250 million.
2.  The new credit agreement extends the borrowing period until March 25, 2030,  allowing for potential increases up to an additional $1 billion.

3. The agreement includes customary affirmative and negative covenants limiting actions such as incurring debt, granting liens, and making acquisitions, subject to exceptions and with certain covenants potentially becoming inapplicable if specific conditions are met.

1. Keysight Technologies, Inc. held its Annual Meeting of Stockholders on March 20, 2025, where all director nominees were elected to new three-year terms and PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP was ratified as the independent registered public accounting firm for fiscal year 2025.
2.  At the Annual Meeting, 155,299,978 shares (89%) of the 172,907,141 outstanding shares were represented, exceeding the quorum requirement.
3.  A non-binding advisory vote to adopt an annual election of directors standard was approved at the Annual Meeting.

1. On March 20, 2025, Microchip Technology Incorporated entered into an underwriting agreement to issue and sell 27,000,000 depositary shares, with an option to purchase an additional 2,700,000 shares, which option was fully exercised.
2. The Depositary Shares Offering, which closed on March 25, 2025, raised approximately $1.32 billion (or $1.45 billion including the over-allotment option).

3.  Holders of the 7.50% Series A Mandatory Convertible Preferred Stock will have their shares automatically convert into between 16.0060 and 19.6080 shares of common stock on or about March 15, 2028, subject to anti-dilution adjustments.
1. Carnival Corporation & plc's Q1 2025 net loss of $78 million represents a $136 million improvement compared to Q1 2024.
2.  The company's total debt increased by $716 million between November 30, 2024, and February 28, 2025, reaching $28.93 billion.
3.  A potential denial of the Italian government's request for continued economic benefits by the European Commission could materially impact Carnival Corporation & plc's financial statements.

1. News Corp's Chief Technology Officer, David Kline, resigned on March 19, 2025, to pursue an external opportunity and will remain with the company until June 30, 2025, to ensure a smooth transition.
2.  The SEC filing, dated March 25, 2025, indicates that Mr. Kline had a five-year tenure with the company, beginning in January 2020.
3. A search for Mr. Kline's successor is underway.

1. Cognizant Technology Solutions Corporation's Board of Directors approved a $2 billion increase to its existing stock repurchase program on March 24, 2025, bringing the total remaining authorization to approximately $3.1 billion.
2. For 2025, the company increased its share repurchase expectation by $500 million to $1.1 billion.
3.  Cognizant anticipates improved relative revenue performance and margin enhancements in 2025, aiming to "return to the Winner's Circle," although specific numbers weren't provided in this filing.

1. Philip Morris International Inc. (PMI) updated its segment reporting on March 25, 2025, to include remaining Wellness and Healthcare results within the Europe segment and renamed its "PMI Duty Free" business to "PMI Global Travel Retail," resulting in four segments: Europe, SSEA, CIS & MEA, EA, AU & PMI GTR, and Americas.
2.  PMI's total net revenues for the full year ended December 31, 2024, were $38,719 million, a 10.1% increase compared to 2023.

3. Exhibits 99.1 and 99.2, incorporated by reference, provide recast unaudited financial information for 2024 vs 2023 and 2023 vs 2022 respectively,  with  no change to PMI's previously reported consolidated financial position or results of operations.
1. News Corp repurchased approximately US$652,261,027.88 worth of Class A and Class B shares as of March 24, 2025, under a US$1 billion stock repurchase program.
2.  On March 24, 2025, 21,324,940 Class A shares and 10,522,944 Class B shares were repurchased, totaling US$432,706,611.73 and US$218,967,539.92 respectively.
3. News Corp intends to continue repurchasing Class A and Class B common stock from time to time, subject to market conditions and other factors.

1. On March 19, 2025, Otis Worldwide Corporation amended its bylaws to revise director nomination procedures, remove limitations on stockholder action by written consent, and eliminate certain director resignation requirements.
2.  The filing does not contain any year-over-year numerical comparisons of financial performance.
3. The amended bylaws, effective March 19, 2025, could potentially impact future shareholder activism and the process of electing directors.
1. Joseph V. Taranto retired as Chair of Everest Group, Ltd.'s Board of Directors, effective after the May 2025 Annual Meeting of Shareholders, with John Graf nominated to succeed him.
2.  Joseph V. Taranto served as Chairman since 1994 and CEO from 1994 to 2013.
3. John Graf, nominated to replace Taranto as Board Chair, has been an independent board member since 2016 and is the Non-Executive Vice Chairman of Global Atlantic Financial Group.
1. On March 23, 2025, Steven J. Moskowitz was terminated as President and CEO of Crown Castle Inc., with Daniel K. Schlanger appointed as Interim President and CEO.

2. Daniel K. Schlanger received a compensation package including a $100,000 monthly stipend and approximately $9.225 million in restricted stock units (RSUs) upon his appointment as Interim President and CEO on March 23, 2025.
3. Crown Castle Inc. expects to close the sale of its Fiber business in the first half of 2026.
1. Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc. (CECONY) entered into a new $500 million 364-day revolving credit agreement on March 24, 2025, replacing an expired agreement.
2.  The new credit agreement allows CECONY to borrow up to $500 million, compared to the previous agreement’s unspecified amount.

3.  The agreement includes covenants restricting CECONY’s debt-to-capital ratio to 0.65 to 1 and limiting liens on assets to 10% of consolidated net tangible assets; failure to comply constitutes an event of default.
1. On March 24, 2025, Cintas Corporation terminated discussions to acquire UniFirst Corporation, citing an inability to reach a mutual agreement on key transaction terms.
2.  The proposed acquisition of UniFirst by Cintas was valued at $275.00 per share, representing a 46% premium over UniFirst's ninety-day average closing price as of January 6, 2025.
3. Cintas plans to continue its growth strategy through disciplined mergers and acquisitions and investment in technology.
1. Lowe's net sales decreased by 3.1% year-over-year to $83.7 billion in fiscal year 2024 (ended January 31, 2025).
2.  Lowe's plans to spend approximately $2.5 billion on capital expenditures in fiscal year 2025.
3.  Lowe's CEO plans to sell up to 58,000 shares of company stock by May 29, 2026.
1.  At the Walt Disney Company's annual shareholder meeting on March 20, 2025, a shareholder proposal requesting a report on climate risks to retirement plan beneficiaries failed to pass.
2.  Overwhelming support was shown for the election of Robert A. Iger to the board of directors, with 1,213,662,424 votes in favor compared to only 6,767,376 against.
3. The ratification of PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP as the independent registered public accountants for fiscal year 2025 passed with 1,374,322,498 votes for and 95,981,468 against.
1. On March 24, 2025, Advanced Micro Devices closed a public offering of $1.5 billion in senior notes, consisting of $875 million in 4.212% notes due 2026 and $625 million in 4.319% notes due 2028.
2.  Also on March 24, 2025, the company issued $950 million in unsecured commercial paper.
3. The company's new debt agreements include covenants limiting the ability to create liens on certain assets, enter into sale and leaseback transactions, and undergo certain mergers or asset sales.
